SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name ........................................... WILLIAM ALEXANDER HOSIE
2. Your address ............................................. 1217 RETALLACK ST., REGINA, SASK.
3. Date ......................................................... MARCH 15TH, 1962
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) ........................................... ALFORD, SCOTLAND
5. What was your father's name and occupation? .............................................................. PETER HOSIE
   Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) ........................................ JULY 1914
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible. ............................................................... CASPER, WYOMING
   Lived there two years after arrival from Scotland in 1912.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.) .................................................. In early twenties.
9. What were your reasons for coming West? I figured there was more opportunities for young men, and two brothers were already settled here, and homesteading in the Silton district. Two young neighbor fellows were bent on going to Wyoming U.S.A. as herders and persuaded me to go along, but I tired of it in two years.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?) ................................................ Through other people and reading about it, and through information from my brothers. There were also pamphlets distributed about the Canadian Golden West.
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Please print all proper names and places names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as it has been given, it's at your dictation.

2. Your full name: Hosie William Alexander

3. Your address: 1517 Ratcliff Rd., Regina, Saskatchewan

4. Date: March 1962

5. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Alford, Scotland

6. What was your father's name and occupation? Peter Hosie, Farmer

7. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): July 1914

8. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan:

   - From Scotland in 1912.
   - Lived there two years after arrival.

9. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.). In early twenties.

10. What were your reasons for coming West? I figured there was more opportunity for young men, and two brothers were already settled here, and homesteading in the Salton district. The young neighbor fellows were bent on going to buying U.S.A., so brothers and I went along, but I tired of it in two years.

11. How did you learn about the West? Through other people reading about it, and through information from my brothers. There were also pamphlets distributed about the Canadian Golden West.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? My parents favoured the idea, as about that time a number of people from that part of Scotland were immigrating to Canada.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? I travelled with two others on their way to Wyoming U.S.A.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Crossed Ocean by ship in 1912 and then used railroad to get to destination in America. Lived only two years there, and came to Saskatchewan in July of 1914 on advice from my brothers.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

Passing through New York on way to Casper Wyoming, we noted many gambling joints, and some sinister characters on the prowl in the hope of luring unsuspected gullible people into their joints. Wyoming was a rough wild country, and every man carried a gun. This being 1912 there wasn't much law or order in that part of the country, only a few Sherriffs scattered here and there.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? Silton Homesteaded at Dummer 1918, and gave it up within a year, after filing, as land was poor.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Dummer

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

In Regina, Weyburn, and Shaunavon, Moose Jaw. Started with the CPR in 1920, worked for CPR out of all these terminals.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

Worked on my father's farm in Scotland, and worked for awhile as a herder in Wyoming, herding cattle and sheep. Started on the CPR engine Dept in 1920 in Regina Sask., worked for them quite steady until the Hungry Thirties came on, and was layed off most of the time, until the war started and brought on the Prosperous Forties.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? My parents favoured the idea, as about that time a number of people from that part of Scotland were immigrating to Canada.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? I travelled with two others on their way to Wyoming U.S.A.

13. What means of transportation did you use? Crossed Ocean by ship in 1912 and then used railroad to get to destination in America. Lived only two years there, and came to Saskatchewan in July of 1914 on advice from my brothers.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.) Passin through New York on way to Casper Wyoming we noted many gambling joints, and some sinister characters on the prowl in the hope of luring unsuspected gullible people into their joints—womping was a rough wild country, and every man carried a gun. This being 1912 there was little law or order in that part of the country, only a few Sheriffs scattered here and there.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? Shifton Homesteaded at Dunner 1913, and gave it up within a year, after filling, as land was poor.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Dunner

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. In Regina, Weyburn, and Shaunavon, Moose Jaw.

Started with the CPR in 1920, worked for CPR out of all these terminals.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came? Worked on my father's farm in Scotland, and worked for awhile as a herder in Wyoming, herding cattle and sheep. Started on the CPR engine Dept in 1920 in Regina Sasks. Worked for them quite steady until the Hungry Thirties came on, and was layed off most of the time, until the war started and brought on the Prosperous Forties.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   Always once a month, and gave them the news of the country.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage. My wife's maiden name was Inez Com... I was married in Weyburn Sask February of 1930. My wife is a Canadian, Irish & Scottish descent.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle? Yes my sister and her husband. Settled first in Regina, then lived for a short while in Calgary Alta.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled. My two older brothers came west in 1905 and 1907 respectively, and settled at Silton, Saskatchewan. My sister & husband in 1919.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record? The hard cold winters were... I helped my brothers on their homesteads, cutting and sawing wood.

A familiar sight in those days on the country roads were the travelling pedlars. They were generally Assyrians or Ruthenians, and would make the rounds twice a year, with clothing, necklaces and cheap jewelry. They travelled by a covered wagon and team, and put up at a farm house when evening over took them.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel? Travelled by team and wagon, sometimes by buggy not too often, generally once a week to a small town for groceries and to pick up the mail.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Always once a month, and have them the news of the country.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage. My wife's maiden name was Mrs. [Name].

I was married in Mayburn Saskatchewan February of 1930. My wife is a Canadian, Irish & Scottish descent.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, please do so below:

Yes, my sister and her husband. Settled first in Regina, then lived for a short while in Calgary Alta.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came west, tell when they came and where they settled. My two older brothers came west in 1905 and 1907 respectively, and settled at Sillton, Saskatchewan. My sister & husband in 1919.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record? The hard cold winters, cutting and sawing wood. A familiar sight in those days on the country roads were the travelling peddlars. They were generally Americans or Northerners, and would make the rounds twice a year, with clothing, nick nacks and cheap jewelry. They travelled by a covered wagon and team, and put up at a farm house when evening over took them.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel? Traveled by team and wagon, some times by buggy not too often, generally once a week to a small town for groceries and to pick up the mail.
25. When was the first car used in the community? Around 1914.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   Never owned a car before 1914.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   In Silton about five miles, in Dummer two miles.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.).

29. How often did you shop in the early days? Generally once a week.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? Around 1914.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   Around 1914 bought clothing and hardware articles through the Catalogues, such as Eaton's and Simpsons. Which many country people still do today.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   With the idea of staying permanently, made the decision before I came.
25. When was the first car used in the community? Around 1914.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?

   In Sifton about five miles; in Burner two miles.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new terms appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

29. How often did you shop in the early days? Generally once a week.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays? Around 1914.

31. Then (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy by this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

   Around 1914, bought clothing and hardware articles through the Catalogues, such as Eaton's and Simpsons, which many country people still do today.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? With the idea of staying permanently, made the decision before I came.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Several Scottish and English families did leave the district, their reasons that the climate was too rigid, and life too lonely at the time.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

A few people in 1930's moved into the cities, as they were dried out on the prairies.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My brother John Hosie was trustee at a school for several years, and organized a Scotch Pipers Brigade in early days at Silton, which was joined by other pipers from Bulyea.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

My brothers wife, Mrs Jean Hosie with the help of other neighbor women organized the Grace Orange Lodge in the twenties, but owing to the lack of members in the late thirties, it was dissolved then. She also organized a ladies circle in the United Church in the thirties.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

The village of Silton was named by a family of early settlers after a place they came from in England.

Regina was named by Princess Louise, daughter of Queen Victoria, which I believe was in 1882, to be correct August 23rd 1882 from the platform of a CPR train, as the name chosen by Princess Louise, wife of Governor-General.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1947? What reasons did they have for moving? Several Scottish and English families did leave the district; their reasons that the climate was too rigid, and life too lonely at the time.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return? A few people in 1930s moved into the city, as they were dried out on the prairies.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates whenever possible. My brother John Hosie was trustee at a school for several years, and organized a Scotch Pipes Brigade in early days at Silton, which was joined by other papers from Blyea.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "firsts" to have or do something in the district section it have given dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.). My brothers wife, Mrs. Jean Hosie with the help of other neighbor women organized the Grace Orange Lodge in the twenties, but owing to the lack of members in the late twenties, it was disbanded then. She also organized a ladies circle in the United Church in the thirties.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given (5) to and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

The village of Silton was named by a family of early settlers after a place they came from in England.

Regina was named by Princess Louise, daughter of Queen Victoria, which I believe was in 1852 to be correct August 22nd 1862 from the platform of a CPR train, as the name chosen by Princess Louise's wife or Governor-General.
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:
Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (describe).

I have a picture of an old threshing scene, when the old wood burning engines were used.

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?

....... (indicate your preference, if any)

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

We have no family of our own.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

Travelling is the most important, as today people all have cars, in some families two or three cars, whereas in the early days, anyone with a horse and buggy considered themselves managing well. Housewives washed on the board in the early days. Musical instruments were generally an organ, some had these long horned gramophones, which first came out by Edison. A far cry from the radio's and big Hi Fi Televisions of today.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

Mrs Jean Webster

Seman's

Sask.
